clinical_study.brief_title: Compare Epidural vs. Lumbar Plexus Analgesia After Hip Arthroplasty
clinical_study.official_title: Compare Effectiveness of Epidural vs. Lumbar Plexus Blocks in Total Hip Arthroplasty (THA) Patients Using Multimodal Pain Control

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this retrospective chart review is to evaluate if the implementation of lumbar plexus block placement for postoperative pain have improved conditions in the postoperative period for patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty when compared to the placement of epidurals for postoperative pain management.

detailed_description.textblock: Primary outcome: 48 hour opiate consumption in patients following THA. ' Secondary outcome: Time to first ambulation, assistance needed with ambulation, opiate and regional related side effects, time to discharge orders.

primary_outcome.description: This is a retrospective, cohort study utilizing electronic medical records to examine patients who underwent primary total hip arthroplasty (THA) at our institution from July,1 2012 till December 17, 2014. Based on previously published studies, 48 hour morphine consumption in the epidural group was expected to be 30mg +/-4mg. Assuming 30mg consumption in the epidural group, a sample size of 58 subjects per group was needed to provide 80% power to detect a 10% change from 30mg in morphine consumption between the epidural and lumbar plexus patients for a two-sided test at a significance level of Î± = 0.05. Calculations were based on a t-test hypothesis testing framework. Since the analysis involved repeated observations of each subject, power was likely underestimated.

secondary_outcome.description: Time of first physical therapy relative to anesthesia end time (hours)
Time of first ambulation relative to anesthesia end time (hours)
Level of assistance needed at at each therapy visit (Functional Independence Measure - FIM - Scale).
Distance ambulated at at each therapy visit (feet).
Time postoperative discharge orders written relative to anesthesia end time (hours)

arm_group.description: Patients received a preoperative lumbar plexus nerve block (20 ml, ropivacaine 0.5%) for postoperative pain management.

Patients received a lumbar epidural preoperatively for postoperative pain management. Epidural infusions of ropivacaine 0.2% were initiated intraoperatively, administered until the morning of postoperative day 1, and titrated to patient comfort.

study_pop.textblock: The study team will identify subject by the Primary Diagnosis of THA, (identified by CPT code 27130) and 2) either a) Epidural (CPT code 62319) or b) Lumbar plexus peripheral nerve block (CPT 62311 or 64449) with the administration of multimodal medication.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years and older
- Diagnosis of:
1. Primary THA, (identified by CPT code 27130)
2. Either a) Epidural (CPT code 62319) or b) Lumbar plexus peripheral nerve block (CPT 62311 or 64449)
- Perioperative multimodal medication
- Hospitalized from July 1, 2012 to December 17, 2014.
Exclusion Criteria:
- THA Revision
- ICU admission postoperatively
- History of dementia
